title: For what values of b, the equation x2−ax+b=0 has a solution for any value of a? - Quora

response.answer_text: If you are interested in complex solutions,  has two solutions for each pair of values . If you are only interested in real solutions, the necessary and sufficient condition is . Since you want a b where there is a solution for every , you must have

Using q,r,and s as the coefficients of the general quadratic equation qx^2+rx+s=0, we know that the discriminant D=r^2–4qs When D > 0 there are two real roots. When D=0, there is one real “double” root. When D < 0, there are no real roots. For the quadratic you have, q=1, r=-a, and s=b D=r^2–4qs=(-a)^2–4(1)(b)=a^2–4b since the coefficient r=-a is squared, r^2 is positive-definite. Moreover, a^2–4b >= 0 for real roots a^2 >= 4b Solution: b <= (a^2)/4
